												I first played this game over 2 years ago when it was offered through EA games website.  Until they shut it down because no one was playing it anymore.  I noticed it was offered through steam and I wanted to come back for 2 main reasons.First, to see if anything had been changed, improved in all that time and the most important one was so when I wrote this review it would be as accurate as possible.  Yes, I did forget about this game and most of the content in 2 years so I wanted to be accurate.First of all let me give you my recommendation, NO, please do not download or play this game.For those of you with no patience it is sid meyers sim city meets micro transactions.The game is a browser game port that requires flash to play.  It is hardwired so that it prefers google chrome flash over adobe flash.  Up to a few days ago if you had a semi modern pc or laptop you could not even get into the game because it did not recognisze a 64 bit flash version as a valid one.  Yes, it was a straight port over from browser to steam.Okay I will step up on my soap box, I personally do not think browser games or phone games belong on steam period.Now I will step off of my soap box and tell you why this game, this Anno Online is bad.Before I do that I want to give 2 points away to those few people who give this a positive review.  It is not pay to win, there  is no PVP at all, barely any combat I will go into that in detail in a bit.  Let us call it what it is, pay to play.  There is someone in the forum who claimed to be able to unlock everything for free but he did spend over 400 days doing it.  I can not confirm or deny it but it does sound about right.  Let me give you a warning here.  If you ever miss one day logging in your loyalty program will drop back to day 1, even if you did spend 2 years playing it.  My second point I will give those few people with a positive review is if you are going to write a review, good or bad please use more then 1 word so it is helpful.  Okay got those out of the way.The game is pretty staright forward.Your little ship shows up on a new island, you build your first house and your first woodcutter.  Total population 1, yeah.Then you will spend the next 8 to 10 hours depending on how familiar you are with sid meyers sim city games to grow your population from 1 pioneer to 1500 vassals. You will make houses, farms, markets and wells, maybe a church here or there.  Then you scratch your head and go, hmmm, now what.  Now you hit the first pay wall.  Your little settlers are asking you to give them linen shirts which takes hemp which your main island does not have.  So now you have 2 choices.  One you can go to the market place and buy a little island with hemp or build an explorer ship and hope to find one.  This process can take anywhere from 1 day if you are really really really lucky to a week to a month depending on what you find.  This is assuming you managed to avoid all those pop ups for micro transactions getting here.  So for arguments sake, you really "don't" have to buy your first island it just helps.Then you have your little island.  You think, lets rename it hemp island or something.  Nope, you can not rename any of your islands or ships.  You repeat the sid meyer city building, a few houses, a few woodcutters and some hemp farms.  Now you make your settlers on your main island happy right??  Ah, not really.  What you find is that the little trade ship you can build, or buy can haul back about 5 shirts.  It will take you at least another little hemp island and another trade ship to make any kind of progession in game at all.Okay so you are still playing, you have your little hemp island and your main island with its 1500 vassals.  By now your pop up help menu has annyoed enough to no end that you will start trying combat.  Combat involves 3 ship types, the brig, the caravel and the galley.  Each one is good against one type, poor against one type and even against ships of the same hull.  You will line up your little ships, hit attack and they move forward like in a chess match and shoot cannons. Period, plain and simple.  Of course you have gem items like chain shot or smoke screens or repair kits to make it a bit more interesting.  For arguments sake, yes you can make these if you get cannon balls as a reward but you will use up way more then you ever get.Still playing, wow, if you managed to finally unlock the next section you will see that your little settlers now are asking for more goods that you can not make on your home island or your little tiny hemp island.  So now you hit your second paywall.  Do you buy a medium sized island, or a large island or a huge island.  Keep in mind they cost up to 19,000 rubies or $60 each and you can own 12 islands currently.In my opinion you can buy the stand alone pc copy Anno 1404 and play it for about $10 and have a better, more complete and fun experience.For a better all round experience I would recommend you pick up any of the Patrician series games, where you can actually move your ships in combat, fire the cannons etc.

												I have been a player of this game since Aug of 2013, when the game was only browser based and in beta. when I first started playing there were several bugs, but in the past year (2014) most of the bugs have been cleared, and a lot of new content and changes have happened.  This game is constantly changing and always for the better.Unlike most Free to play games, Anno Online has NO PVP, which makes for a different environment.  My fellow players and myself have a very helpful community VS one out to kill each other.  Another thing that sets Anno Online apart from the others is that you don't need to buy the ingame currency to get anywhere, all you need is a little amount of time... I didn't hit the top population on the starting island till a year after I started playing, but no other player insulted me, or kicked me out of their guild because i hadn't hit the "End Game".  Game play of Anno Online is very much like Anno 1404 AKA Dawn of Discovery (in North America), Except for a few major changes;1) There is no Spice/indigo/silk Islands - all the oriental goods that you made in 1404 are instead Sold by a NPC vendor2) Monuments -  In Anno Online Monuments are 100% different and there are more monuments than in any other Anno game.3) Island colonization - there is no NPC stealing the island you wanted in Anno online, you find islands for yourself and only yourself, they are 100% random and very different... but i will admit it's hard to find just the "right" island4) Interactions with other players - you help your neighbors in Anno online by sending buffs or your constructor over to their islands, and in turn you get rewarded for some of it... there is no hostile interactions between players.5) Construction - in Anno online, you can move buildings with no resource penalty but deleting you only get back 1/4th of what you put in. VS other Anno games where if you put a building down you have to delete to put it somewhere else, which in most missions you lose 1/2 resources.6)Combat-  In anno games you control the ships and they fight the other ships in real time with little to no rewards... in Anno Online, Possibly cause it's too much strain on the servers the combat is Turn Based, but every combat you enter gives you rewards, these rewards can be spent on fun things to boost your economy with one issue, it's a strain on your economy early on to be building up and doing PVE, and many veteran players suggest doing the PVE to mid/late stages of the game.Now it isn't a proper review without posting a few negative points;1) Zone locks- these freaks of nature can hurt, and sadly seem more frequent now with more players coming in from the steam community, but there is 2 ways that I know BB handles these... first is the auto script, it runs every day at midnight server time (8pm eastern time)- 90% of zone locks are fixed this way... I have had a zone lock and the auto script handled it.   The other way is BB has to go in and find the error, sadly this takes time and can take from days to weeks to even a month in some cases. however sad you do get reimbursed for time lost.2) Minor combat bugs - since this latest patch these might not show up... but on some maps after attacking and winning a boat may get 'stuck' and becomes unusable... i haven't seen if the map is still in the game after this last patch but they can happen if near an island for combat.3) Construction- losing 3/4 of resources spent is a major blow if you built the wrong building.4) early game - it's slow... very slow but that's why we have our friendly chat system to make you forget how long something takes.5) As with all multiplayer games, Trolls  just can't avoid them on the internet.6) This one is more personal- can't use steam client with the web started accounts.  This is something I would love to be added in the future.7) lack of a 2nd ruby cutter... would be nice to cut rubies faster... but it's again a personal complaint.All in all I like the game and would recommend it to others!Since writing this post I started working on a US based fan site for Anno Online.If you are looking for more information about the game, head over to AnnoAddiction.com

Sometimes you will progress very slowly and you will even think that you do not progress at all, but sometimes your progress could be fast as a bullet, shot from AK-47.The economy is typical to the Anno games- for some tools and equipement you will need another one, created from a resource.You discover new islands but you need to unlock the slot first.The premium currency are gems. But because I have a building that actually I can make gems, I feel like I do not need to spend a cent for the game. You have daily log-in reward and every 7th day, you get some raw gems that you can transfer to real gems and use them. After you upgrade your building 240 raw gems = 240 gems, but before that it is 240 raw gems = 120 gems, so you better upgrade that building first.There are people in the chat if you want to chat. The game is not dead at all. There are many people.The graphics are good for the eye and you will enjoy them.This game have naval combats, but they are dumb as♥♥♥♥♥♥ I mean, you have to grind like a mad man to progress. I really do not enjoy this and I really do not make naval battles. You really do not need them to progress. So I suggest you skip this♥♥♥♥♥♥and probably come back when you reach your max level of lighthouse, which you can use total of 49 ships, with no upgrades. So yes, there is a ship limiter too.But it is nice to see your harbours with the many ships that come and go with resources, trade ships that come to deliver the goods or buy some goods.So I have unlocked all the buildings. This means that I have an island with more than 4000 nobles, which are really hard to get.Of course if you pay and get many gems, you will progress extremely fast.Overall I suggest this game if you have the patience to play it.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2015
												Where to start.... First, I gave this game a thumbs down because there isn't a "Meh" option.  It's not terrible, but there are definitely better games out there, and I never recommend that anyone waste their time.I tried really hard to like this game.  I gave it every possible chance to impress me..... but, no dice.  Frankly, it is under-featured, the gameplay is dated (at a date somewhere around 1991), and the development team seems so obsessed with controlling possibly offensive content that they have gutted any form or fashion of customization.  If you do play, take care choosing your nick-name, since it's the last thing you get to customize.  All island and ship-names are generated by the game.  So much for immersion.  I got saddled early on with two islands with the same name, and no options to fix it, which was prohibitively confusing, considering you have to coordinate shipping routes between these islands to grow the economy.  As far as city builders go, again, it's a "meh".  With no competitive play and the weakest PVE system I've seen in years, building and upgrading are monotonous and repetitive almost to pointlessness.  It was only a sense of "this game can't break me"  that got me to care at all.So, now that the reason for the thumbs down is out of the way, here are the good points, kind of.  I have only played on the UK "Mermaid" server, so I don't know if all of these factors are consistent from server to server.The moderators:  The mods were polite, and as helpful as they could be.  Apparently, however, their powers don't extend much beyond kicking people from the chat and answering an occasional question.  Twice I have been told by moderators that they had no experience with the Steam Client, and thus couldn't help with Steam-related issues.  The players:  This is the friendliest, most helpful game community I have ever seen.  The global chat looks like a constant beginner's tutorial, as players take time out from their own game to answer questions and fill in the gaps for the un-necessarily cryptic quest instructions  and inadequate game documentation.  Why did I play for seven weeks?  Because the players were fun, even if the game wasn't.  The price:  It's free.  I have, however, played many, many much better developed free2play games.In the end, it's a shame, because there are building blocks here that could have been a really good game TWENTY YEARS AGO.  But, it's 2015, and experienced gamers (of which you will not find many on Anno-Online) have expectations of gameplay, challenge, immersion, and graphics that this game does not meet in any way.  I would seriously recommend to the developers that they play some of the games made by the competition, and get some idea of how a contemporary city-building game should look, play and work.Lastly, I am a longtime fan of Ubisoft games.  If you likerd their blockbuster titles, or even the Anno franchise, do not assume that this game comes anywhere close to the quality of those games.2.5/10  I might log in now and again to say hello to the nice people I met in chat.

Posted: February 4, 2016
												Like most free-to-play games, Anno Online starts out at a brisk pace but after you have invested enough time to be interested in the game, it gets slower and slower - unless you spend money.  All "free" games have to make money somehow and walking that fine line between being frustrating enough to make you buy things and so frustrating you quit playing is the difference between success and failure.  This game can be played with no money at all, but only very slowly.Fans of the game like to point out it doesn't require money because there is no "winning" the game and that's true.   It's a city builder and that genre doesn't usually involve competition.  But it's a very repetitive city builder that goes at a snail's pace.  The advice one hears most often in the game's chat is "patience".Pros: the graphics are beautiful; the software doesn't crash; the chat and moderators are helpful and the first city on the first island is a lot of fun.  Cons: the game has lots of lag; only happy talk is allowed in chat; all the cities are just like the first city; the sea battles are repetitive and mechanical and endless; the trading ships are surprisingly underdeveloped - they goe A to B and that's it, plus, they have to be stopped and reprogrammed to make any change in cargo (takes half an hour); leaving the game unattended for a day invites disaster; the challenges are more inventory management than strategy.I played for a long time and that should cause a "Yes" recommendation, but to be honest, after the first couple of days I kept on playing more out of stubborness than enjoyment.  In retrospect, I wish I had picked a different game.  BTW the game takes so long to open I usually leave it connected all day so the hours I've logged are not actual playing time.

												Like most free-to-play games, Anno Online starts out at a brisk pace but after you have invested enough time to be interested in the game, it gets slower and slower - unless you spend money.  All "free" games have to make money somehow and walking that fine line between being frustrating enough to make you buy things and so frustrating you quit playing is the difference between success and failure.  This game can be played with no money at all, but only very slowly.Fans of the game like to point out it doesn't require money because there is no "winning" the game and that's true.   It's a city builder and that genre doesn't usually involve competition.  But it's a very repetitive city builder that goes at a snail's pace.  The advice one hears most often in the game's chat is "patience".Pros: the graphics are beautiful; the software doesn't crash; the chat and moderators are helpful and the first city on the first island is a lot of fun.  Cons: the game has lots of lag; only happy talk is allowed in chat; all the cities are just like the first city; the sea battles are repetitive and mechanical and endless; the trading ships are surprisingly underdeveloped - they goe A to B and that's it, plus, they have to be stopped and reprogrammed to make any change in cargo (takes half an hour); leaving the game unattended for a day invites disaster; the challenges are more inventory management than strategy.I played for a long time and that should cause a "Yes" recommendation, but to be honest, after the first couple of days I kept on playing more out of stubborness than enjoyment.  In retrospect, I wish I had picked a different game.  BTW the game takes so long to open I usually leave it connected all day so the hours I've logged are not actual playing time.
